cleaned_text: Natural gas Natural gas (also called fossil gas, methane gas or simply gas) is a naturally occurring mixture of gaseous [hydrocarbons](/wiki/Hydrocarbon) consisting primarily of [methane](/wiki/Methane) in addition to various smaller amounts of other higher [alkanes](/wiki/Alkane). Low levels of trace gases like [carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide), [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen), [hydrogen sulfide](/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide), and [helium](/wiki/Helium) [[1]](#cite_note-1) Methane is colorless and odorless, and the second largest greenhouse gas contributor to global climate change after carbon dioxide. [[2]](#cite_note-:0-2) Because natural gas is odorless, [odorizers](/wiki/Odorizer) such as [mercaptan](/wiki/Methanethiol) (which smells like sulfur or rotten eggs) are commonly added to it for safety so that leaks can be readily detected. [[3]](#cite_note-3) Natural gas is a [fossil fuel](/wiki/Fossil_fuel) and [non-renewable resource](/wiki/Non-renewable_resource) that is formed when layers of [organic matter](/wiki/Organic_matter) (primarily marine microorganisms) [[4]](#cite_note-4) decompose under [anaerobic](/wiki/Anaerobic_digestion) conditions and are subjected to intense heat and pressure underground over millions of years. [[5]](#cite_note-eiaex-5) The energy that the decayed organisms originally obtained from the sun via [photosynthesis](/wiki/Photosynthesis) is stored as chemical energy within the molecules of methane and other hydrocarbons. [[6]](#cite_note-epa_ng-6) Natural gas can be burned for heating, cooking, [[7]](#cite_note-7) and [electricity generation](/wiki/Gas-fired_power_plant). It is also used as a chemical [feedstock](/wiki/Raw_material) in the manufacture of [plastics](/wiki/Plastic) and other commercially important [organic chemicals](/wiki/Organic_chemicals) and less commonly used as a [fuel for vehicles](/wiki/Natural_gas_vehicle). The extraction and consumption of natural gas is a major and growing contributor to [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change). [[8]](#cite_note-8) [[9]](#cite_note-ieaco2-9) [[10]](#cite_note-owidebf-10) Both the gas itself (specifically [methane](/wiki/Methane_emissions)) and [carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_in_Earth%27s_atmosphere), which is released when natural gas is burned, are [greenhouse gases](/wiki/Greenhouse_gas). [[11]](#cite_note-11) [[12]](#cite_note-AGI-12) When burned for [heat](/wiki/Furnace_(central_heating)) or [electricity](/wiki/Gas-fired_power_plant), natural gas emits fewer toxic air pollutants, less carbon dioxide, and almost no particulate matter compared to other fossil and [biomass](/wiki/Biomass) fuels. [[13]](#cite_note-13) However, [gas venting](/wiki/Gas_venting) and unintended [fugitive emissions](/wiki/Fugitive_emissions) throughout the [supply chain](/wiki/Supply_chain) can result in natural gas having a similar [carbon footprint](/wiki/Carbon_footprint) to other fossil fuels overall. [[14]](#cite_note-14) Natural gas can be found in underground [geological formations](/wiki/Geological_formation), often alongside other fossil fuels like [coal](/wiki/Coal) and [oil](/wiki/Petroleum) (petroleum). Most natural gas has been created through either biogenic or thermogenic processes. Biogenic gas is formed when in [marshes](/wiki/Marsh), [bogs](/wiki/Bog), [landfills](/wiki/Landfill), and shallow sediments anaerobically decompose but are not subjected to high temperatures and pressures. Thermogenic gas takes a much longer period of time to form and is created when organic matter is heated and compressed deep underground. [[15]](#cite_note-15) [[5]](#cite_note-eiaex-5) During petroleum production, natural gas is sometimes [flared](/wiki/Gas_flare) rather than being collected and used. Before natural gas can be burned as a fuel or used in manufacturing processes, it almost always has to be [processed](/wiki/Natural_gas_processing) to remove impurities such as water. The byproducts of this processing include [ethane](/wiki/Ethane), [propane](/wiki/Propane), [butanes](/wiki/Butane), [pentanes](/wiki/Pentane), and higher molecular weight hydrocarbons. Hydrogen be converted into pure dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide), [water vapor](/wiki/Water_vapor), and sometimes [helium](/wiki/Helium) and [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen) must also be removed. Natural gas is sometimes informally referred to simply as "gas", especially when it is being compared to other energy sources, such as oil, coal or renewables. However, it is not to be confused with [gasoline](/wiki/Gasoline), which is often shortened in colloquial usage to "gas", especially in North America. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Natural gas is measured in [standard cubic meters](/wiki/Standard_cubic_meter) or [standard cubic feet](/wiki/Standard_cubic_feet). The density compared to air ranges from 0.58 (16.8 g/mole, 0.71 kg per standard cubic meter) to as high as 0.79 (22.9 g/mole, 0.97 kg per scm), but generally less than 0.64 (18.5 g/mole, 0.78 kg per scm). [[17]](#cite_note-17) For comparison, pure methane (16.0425 g/mole) has a density 0.5539 times that of air (0.678 kg per standard cubic meter). Name[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=1)] In the early 1800s, natural gas became known as "natural" to distinguish it from the dominant gas fuel at the time, [coal gas](/wiki/Coal_gas). [[18]](#cite_note-18) Unlike coal gas, which is manufactured by heating coal, natural gas can be extracted from the ground in its native gaseous form. When the use of natural gas overtook the use of coal gas in English speaking countries in the 20th century, it was increasingly referred to as simply "gas." [[19]](#cite_note-19) In order to highlight its role in exacerbating the [climate crisis](/wiki/Climate_crisis), however, many organizations have criticized the continued use of the word "natural" in referring to the gas. These advocates prefer the term "fossil gas" or "methane gas" as better conveying to the public its climate threat. [[20]](#cite_note-20) [[21]](#cite_note-21) [[22]](#cite_note-22) A 2020 study of Americans' perceptions of the fuel found that, across political identifications, the term "methane gas" led to better estimates of its harms and risks. [[23]](#cite_note-23) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=2)] Natural gas can come out of the ground and cause a long-burning fire. In [ancient Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece), the gas flames at [Mount Chimaera](/wiki/Mount_Chimaera) contributed to the legend of the fire-breathing creature [Chimera](/wiki/Chimera_(mythology)). In [ancient China](/wiki/Ancient_China), gas resulting from the drilling for [brines](/wiki/Brine_(solution)) was first used by about 400 BC. [[24]](#cite_note-24) The Chinese transported gas seeping from the ground in crude pipelines of bamboo to where it was used to boil salt water to [extract the salt](/wiki/Salt_in_Chinese_history) in the [Ziliujing District](/wiki/Ziliujing_District) of [Sichuan](/wiki/Sichuan). [[25]](#cite_note-25) [[26]](#cite_note-26) Natural gas was not widely used before the development of long distance pipelines in the early twentieth century. Before that, most use was near to the source of the well, and the predominant gas for fuel and lighting during the industrial revolution was manufactured coal gas. [[27]](#cite_note-27) The history of natural gas in the United States begins with localized use. In the seventeenth century, French missionaries witnessed the American Indians setting fire to natural gas seeps around lake Erie, and scattered observations of these seeps were made by European-descended settlers throughout the eastern seaboard through the 1700s. [[28]](#cite_note-:1-28) In 1821, William Hart dug the first commercial natural gas well in the United States at [Fredonia, New York](/wiki/Fredonia,_New_York), United States, which led in 1858 to the formation of the [Fredonia Gas Light Company](/wiki/Fredonia_Gas_Light_Company). [[29]](#cite_note-29) Further such ventures followed near wells in other states, until technological innovations allowed the growth of major long distance pipelines from the 1920s onward. [[28]](#cite_note-:1-28) By 2009, 66,000 km3 (16,000 cu mi) (or 8%) had been used out of the total 850,000 km3 (200,000 cu mi) of estimated remaining recoverable reserves of natural gas. [[30]](#cite_note-worldenergyoutlook.org-30) Sources[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=3)] Natural gas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=4)] In the 19th century, natural gas was primarily obtained as a by-product of [producing oil](/wiki/Oil_well). The small, light gas carbon chains came out of solution as the extracted fluids underwent pressure reduction from the [reservoir](/wiki/Petroleum_reservoir) to the surface, similar to uncapping a soft drink bottle where the carbon dioxide [effervesces](/wiki/Effervesce). The gas was often viewed as a by-product, a hazard, and a disposal problem in active oil fields. The large volumes produced could not be used until relatively expensive [pipeline](/wiki/Pipeline_transport) and [storage](/wiki/Natural_gas_storage) facilities were constructed to deliver the gas to consumer markets. Until the early part of the 20th century, most natural gas associated with oil was either simply released or [burned off](/wiki/Gas_flare) at oil fields. [Gas venting](/wiki/Gas_venting) and [production flaring](/wiki/Production_flaring) are still practised in modern times, but efforts are ongoing around the world to retire them, and to replace them with other commercially viable and useful alternatives. [[31]](#cite_note-31) [[32]](#cite_note-32) Unwanted gas (or [stranded gas](/wiki/Stranded_gas_reserve) without a market) is often returned to the reservoir with 'injection' wells while awaiting a possible future market or to re-pressurize the formation, which can enhance oil extraction rates from other wells. In regions with a high natural gas demand (such as the US), [pipelines](/wiki/Pipeline_transport) are constructed when it is economically feasible to transport gas from a wellsite to an [end consumer](/wiki/End_consumer). In addition to transporting gas via pipelines for use in power generation, other end uses for natural gas include export as [liquefied natural gas](/wiki/LNG) (LNG) or conversion of natural gas into other liquid products via [gas to liquids](/wiki/Gas_to_liquids) (GTL) technologies. GTL technologies can convert natural gas into liquids products such as gasoline, diesel or jet fuel. A variety of GTL technologies have been developed, including [Fischer-Tropsch](/wiki/Fischer%E2%80%93Tropsch) (F-T), methanol to gasoline (MTG) and [syngas to gasoline plus](/wiki/Syngas_to_gasoline_plus) (STG+). F-T produces a synthetic crude that can be further refined into finished products, while MTG can produce synthetic gasoline from natural gas. STG+ can produce drop-in gasoline, diesel, jet fuel and aromatic chemicals directly from natural gas via a single-loop process. [[33]](#cite_note-STG+-33) In 2011, [Royal Dutch Shell's](/wiki/Royal_Dutch_Shell) 140,000 barrels (22,000 m3) per day F-T plant went into operation in [Qatar](/wiki/Qatar). [[34]](#cite_note-34) Natural gas can be "associated" (found in [oil fields](/wiki/Oil_field)), or "non-associated" (isolated in [natural gas fields](/wiki/Natural_gas_field)), found in [coal beds](/wiki/Coal_bed) (as [coalbed methane](/wiki/Coalbed_methane)). [[35]](#cite_note-35) It sometimes of [ethane](/wiki/Ethane), [propane](/wiki/Propane), [butane](/wiki/Butane), and [pentane](/wiki/Pentane)—heavier hydrocarbons removed for commercial use prior to the [methane](/wiki/Methane) being sold as a consumer fuel or chemical plant feedstock. Non-hydrocarbons such as [carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide), [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen), [helium](/wiki/Helium) (rarely), and [hydrogen sulfide](/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide) must also be removed before the natural gas can be transported. [[36]](#cite_note-36) Natural gas extracted from oil wells is called casinghead gas (whether or not truly produced up the annulus and through a casinghead outlet) or associated gas. Sources that consider that Russia has by far the largest proven reserves include the US [Central Intelligence km3, [[41]](#cite_note-41) which would place it in second, slightly behind Iran (33,100 to 33,800 km3, depending on the source). It is estimated that there are about 900,000 km3 of "unconventional" gas such as shale gas, of which 180,000 km3 may be recoverable. [[42]](#cite_note-42) In turn, many studies from [MIT](/wiki/MIT), [Black & Veatch](/wiki/Black_%26_Veatch) and the [US Department of Energy](/wiki/US_Department_of_Energy) predict that natural gas will account for a larger portion of electricity generation and heat in the future. [[43]](#cite_note-43)[ [better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)] The world's largest gas field is the offshore [South Pars / North Dome Gas-Condensate field](/wiki/South_Pars_/_North_Dome_Gas-Condensate_field), shared between Iran and Qatar. It is estimated to have 51,000 cubic kilometers (12,000 cu mi) of natural gas and 50 billion barrels (7.9 billion cubic meters) of [natural gas condensates](/wiki/Natural-gas_condensate). Because natural gas is not a pure product, as the reservoir pressure drops when non-associated gas is extracted from a field under [supercritical](/wiki/Supercritical_fluid) (pressure/temperature) conditions, the higher molecular weight components may partially condense upon isothermic depressurizing—an effect called [retrograde condensation](/wiki/Retrograde_condensation). The liquid thus formed may get trapped as the pores of the gas reservoir get depleted. One method to deal with this problem is to re-inject dried gas free of condensate to maintain the underground pressure and to allow re-evaporation and extraction of condensates. More frequently, the liquid condenses at the surface, and one of the tasks of the [gas plant](/wiki/Natural_gas_processing) is to collect this condensate. The resulting liquid is called natural gas liquid (NGL) and has commercial value. Shale gas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=5)] Shale gas is natural gas produced from [shale](/wiki/Shale). Because shale has matrix permeability too low to allow gas to flow in economical quantities, shale gas wells depend on fractures to allow the gas to flow. Early shale gas wells depended on natural fractures through which gas flowed; almost all shale gas wells today require fractures artificially created by [hydraulic fracturing](/wiki/Hydraulic_fracturing). Since 2000, shale gas has become a major source of natural gas in the United States and Canada. [[44]](#cite_note-44) Because of increased shale gas production the United States was in 2014 the number one natural gas producer in the world. [[45]](#cite_note-45) The production of shale gas in the United States has been described as a "shale gas revolution" and as "one of the landmark events in the 21st century." [[46]](#cite_note-46) Following the increased production in the United States, shale gas exploration is beginning in countries such as Poland, China, and South Africa. [[47]](#cite_note-47) [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) Chinese geologists have identified the [Sichuan Basin](/wiki/Sichuan_Basin) as a promising target for shale gas drilling, because of the similarity of shales to those that have proven productive in the United States. Production from the Wei-201 well is between 10,000 and 20,000 m3 per day. [[50]](#cite_note-50) In late 2020, China National Petroleum Corporation claimed daily production of 20 million cubic meters of gas from its Changning-Weiyuan demonstration zone. [[51]](#cite_note-51)[ [unreliable source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources)] Town gas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=6)] [Town gas](/wiki/Town_gas) is a flammable gaseous fuel made by the destructive distillation of [coal](/wiki/Coal). It contains a variety of calorific gases including [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen), [carbon monoxide](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide), [methane](/wiki/Methane), and other volatile [hydrocarbons](/wiki/Hydrocarbon), together with small quantities of non-calorific gases such as [carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide) and [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen), and was used in a similar way to natural gas. This is a historical technology and is not usually economically competitive with other sources of fuel gas today. Most town "gashouses" located in the eastern US in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were simple by-product [coke](/wiki/Coke_(fuel)) ovens that heated bituminous coal in air-tight chambers. The gas driven off from the coal was collected and distributed through networks of pipes to residences and other buildings where it was used for cooking and lighting. (Gas heating did not come into widespread use until the last half of the 20th century.) The [coal tar](/wiki/Coal_tar) (or [asphalt](/wiki/Bitumen)) that collected in the bottoms of the gashouse ovens was often used for roofing and other waterproofing purposes, and when mixed with sand and gravel was used for paving streets. Crystallized natural gas - clathrates[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=7)] Huge quantities of natural gas (primarily methane) exist in the form of [clathrates](/wiki/Methane_clathrate) under sediment on offshore continental shelves and on land in arctic regions that experience [permafrost](/wiki/Permafrost), such as those in [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia). Hydrates require a combination of high pressure and low temperature to form. In 2013, Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation (JOGMEC) announced that they had recovered commercially relevant quantities of natural gas from methane hydrate. It reached 24.1 trillion cubic feet per year in 1973, followed by a decline, and reached 24.5 trillion cubic feet in 2001. After a brief drop, withdrawals increased nearly every year since 2006 (owing to the [shale gas boom](/wiki/Shale_gas_in_the_United_States#Barnett_and_beyond)), with 2017 production at 33.4 trillion cubic feet and 2019 production at 40.7 trillion cubic feet. After the third peak in December 2019, extraction continued to fall from March onward due to decreased demand caused by the [COVID-19 pandemic in the US](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States). [[57]](#cite_note-EIAThirdPeak-57) The [2021 global energy crisis](/wiki/2021_global_energy_crisis) was driven by a global surge in demand as the world quit the economic recession caused by COVID-19, particularly due to strong energy demand in Asia. [[58]](#cite_note-58) Storage and transport[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=10)] This section needs to be updated. The reason given is: change in transport from Russia.(May 2022) Because of its low density, it is not easy to store natural gas or to transport it by vehicle. Natural gas [pipelines](/wiki/Pipeline_transport) are impractical across oceans, since the gas needs to be cooled down and compressed, as the friction in the pipeline causes the gas to heat up. Many [existing pipelines in the US](/wiki/List_of_natural_gas_pipelines#North_America) are close to reaching their capacity, prompting some politicians representing northern states to speak of potential shortages. The large trade cost implies that natural gas markets are globally much less integrated, causing significant price differences across countries. In [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe), the gas pipeline network is already dense. [[60]](#cite_note-60)[ [better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)][ [full citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include)] New pipelines are planned or under construction between Western Europe and the [Near East](/wiki/Near_East) or [Northern Africa](/wiki/Northern_Africa). [[61]](#cite_note-61) Whenever gas is bought or sold at custody transfer points, rules and agreements are made regarding the gas quality. These may include the maximum allowable concentration of [CO2](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide), [H](/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide)and 2S 2S [H](/wiki/Water_vapor). Usually sales quality gas that has been 2O 2O [treated to remove contamination](/wiki/Natural-gas_processing)is traded on a "dry gas" basis and is required to be commercially free from objectionable odours, materials, and dust or other solid or liquid matter, waxes, gums and gum forming constituents, which might damage or adversely affect operation of equipment downstream of the custody transfer point. [LNG carrier](/wiki/LNG_carrier) ships transport [liquefied natural gas](/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas) (LNG) across oceans, while [tank trucks](/wiki/Tank_truck) can carry LNG or compressed natural gas (CNG) over shorter distances. [[62]](#cite_note-62) Sea transport using [CNG carrier](/wiki/CNG_carrier) ships that are now under development may be competitive with LNG transport in specific conditions.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Gas is turned into liquid at a [liquefaction](/wiki/Liquefaction_of_gases) plant, and is returned to gas form at [regasification](/wiki/Gasification) plant at the [terminal](/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas_terminal). Shipborne regasification equipment is also used. LNG is the preferred form for long distance, high volume transportation of natural gas, whereas pipeline is preferred for transport for distances up to 4,000 km (2,500 mi) over land and approximately half that distance offshore. [CNG](/wiki/CNG) is transported at high pressure, typically above 200 [bars](/wiki/Bar_(unit)) (20,000 kPa; 2,900 psi). Compressors and decompression equipment are less capital intensive and may be economical in smaller unit sizes than liquefaction/regasification plants. Natural gas trucks and carriers may transport natural gas directly to end-users, or to distribution points such as pipelines. In the past, the natural gas which was recovered in the course of recovering [petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum) could not be profitably sold, and was simply burned at the oil field in a process known as [flaring](/wiki/Gas_flare). Flaring is now illegal in many countries. [[63]](#cite_note-63) Additionally, higher demand in the last 20-30 years has made production of gas associated with oil economically viable. As a further option, the gas is now sometimes re- [injected](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inject) into the formation for [enhanced oil recovery](/wiki/Enhanced_oil_recovery) by pressure maintenance as well as miscible or immiscible flooding. Conservation, re-injection, or flaring of natural gas associated with oil is primarily dependent on proximity to markets (pipelines), and regulatory restrictions. Natural gas can be indirectly exported through the absorption in other physical output. A recent study suggests that the expansion of shale gas production in the US has caused prices to drop relative to other countries. This has caused a boom in energy intensive manufacturing sector exports, whereby the average dollar unit of US manufacturing exports has almost tripled its energy content between 1996 and 2012. [[64]](#cite_note-64) A "master gas system" was invented in [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia) in the late 1970s, ending any necessity for flaring. Satellite and nearby infra-red camera observations, however, shows that flaring [[65]](#cite_note-65) [[66]](#cite_note-66) [[67]](#cite_note-67) [[68]](#cite_note-68) and venting [[69]](#cite_note-69) are still happening in some countries. Natural gas is used to generate electricity and heat for [desalination](/wiki/Desalination). Similarly, some landfills that also discharge methane gases have been set up to capture the methane and generate electricity. Natural gas is often stored underground [references about geological storage needed]inside depleted gas reservoirs from previous gas wells, [salt domes](/wiki/Salt_domes), or in tanks as liquefied natural gas. The gas is injected in a time of low demand and extracted when demand picks up. Storage nearby end users helps to meet volatile demands, but such storage may not always be practicable. With 15 countries accounting for 84% of the worldwide extraction, access to natural gas has become an important issue in international politics, and countries vie for control of pipelines. [[70]](#cite_note-70) In the first decade of the 21st century, [Gazprom](/wiki/Gazprom), the state-owned energy company in Russia, engaged in disputes with [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine) and [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus) over the price of natural gas, which have created concerns that gas deliveries to parts of Europe could be cut off for political reasons. [[71]](#cite_note-71) The United States is preparing to export natural gas. [[72]](#cite_note-72) Floating liquefied natural gas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=11)] [Floating liquefied natural gas](/wiki/Floating_liquefied_natural_gas) (FLNG) is an innovative technology designed to enable the development of offshore gas resources that would otherwise remain untapped due to environmental or economic factors which currently make them impractical to develop via a land-based LNG operation. FLNG technology also provides a number of environmental and economic advantages: - Environmental - Because all processing is done at the gas field, there is no requirement for long pipelines to shore, compression units to pump the gas to shore, dredging and jetty construction, and onshore construction of an LNG processing plant, which significantly reduces the environmental footprint. [[73]](#cite_note-73)Avoiding construction also helps preserve marine and coastal environments. In addition, environmental disturbance will be minimised during decommissioning because the facility can easily be disconnected and removed before being refurbished and re-deployed elsewhere. - Economic - Where pumping gas to shore can be prohibitively expensive, FLNG makes development economically viable. As a result, it will open up new business opportunities for countries to develop offshore gas fields that would otherwise remain stranded, such as those offshore East Africa. [[74]](#cite_note-74) Many gas and oil companies are considering the economic and environmental benefits of floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG). There are currently projects underway to construct five FLNG facilities. [Petronas](/wiki/Petronas) is close to completion on their FLNG-1 [[75]](#cite_note-75) at [Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering](/wiki/Daewoo_Shipbuilding_and_Marine_Engineering) and are underway on their FLNG-2 project [[76]](#cite_note-76) at [Samsung Heavy Industries](/wiki/Samsung_Heavy_Industries). [Shell [[78]](#cite_note-78) Uses[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=12)] Natural gas is primarily used in the northern hemisphere. North America and Europe are major consumers. Often well head gases require removal of various hydrocarbon molecules contained within the gas. Some of these gases include [heptane](/wiki/Heptane), [pentane](/wiki/Pentane), [propane](/wiki/Propane) and other hydrocarbons with molecular weights above [methane](/wiki/Methane) (CH 4). The natural gas transmission lines extend to the natural gas processing plant or unit which removes the higher-molecular weight hydrocarbons to produce natural gas with energy content between 35-39 megajoules per cubic metre (950-1,050 British thermal units per cubic foot). The processed natural gas may then be used for residential, commercial and industrial uses. Mid-stream natural gas[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=13)] Natural gas flowing in the distribution lines is called mid-stream natural gas and is often used to power engines which rotate compressors. These compressors are required in the transmission line to pressurize and repressurize the mid-stream natural gas as the gas travels. Typically, natural gas powered engines require 35-39 MJ/m3 (950-1,050 BTU/cu ft) natural gas to operate at the rotational name plate specifications. [[79]](#cite_note-american-environmental-79) Several methods are used to remove these higher molecular weighted gases for use by the natural gas engine. A few technologies are as to [generate electricity](/wiki/Electricity_generation). Gas-fired power plants generate almost a quarter of [world electricity](/wiki/Electric_energy_consumption)and are significant sources of [greenhouse gas emissions](/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions). [[80]](#cite_note-80)However, they can provide seasonal, [dispatchable compensate for [variable renewable energy](/wiki/Variable_renewable_energy)deficits, where [hydropower](/wiki/Hydropower)or [interconnectors](/wiki/Electrical_interconnector)are not available. Domestic use[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Natural_gas&action=edit§ion=15)] In the USA, over one-third of households (>40 million homes) cook with gas. [[2]](#cite_note-:0-2) Natural gas dispensed in a residential setting can generate temperatures in excess of 1,100 °C (2,000 °F) making it a powerful domestic cooking and heating fuel. [[136]](#cite_note-136) In hydraulic fracturing, well operators force water mixed with a variety of chemicals through the wellbore casing into the rock. Sand and other particles are added to the water as a [proppant](/wiki/Proppant) to keep the fractures in the rock open, thus enabling the gas to flow into the casing and then to the surface. Chemicals are added to the fluid to perform such functions as reducing friction and inhibiting corrosion. After the "frack", oil or gas is extracted and 30-70% of the frack fluid, i.e. the mixture of water, chemicals, sand, etc., flows back to the surface. Many gas-bearing formations also contain water, which will flow up the wellbore to the surface along with the gas, in both hydraulically fractured and non-hydraulically fractured wells. This [produced water](/wiki/Produced_water) often has a high content of salt and other dissolved minerals that occur in the formation. [[137]](#cite_note-137) The volume of water used to hydraulically fracture wells varies according to the hydraulic fracturing technique.
